title: 103_hr5245
content: The "Housing Programs Extension Act of 1994" may be cited as the short title. This Act provides housing assistance. The "Housing Programs Extension Act of 1994" requires the Secretary of Housing and Urban Development to offer a 24-month extension to expiring Section 8 contracts for housing projects, with terms identical to the original contract. The "Housing Programs Extension Act of 1994" mandates a 24-month extension for expiring Section 8 contracts, providing displacement assistance to tenants through tenant-based or project-based assistance under the United States Housing Act of 1937. The Housing Programs Extension Act of 1994 mandates an extension for expiring Section 8 contracts, providing displacement assistance to tenants under the United States Housing Act of 1937 by amending the determination of median income and eligible uses of emergency modernization funds. Amendment to 14(k)(1) of the United States Housing Act of 1937 reduces funding from $75,000,000 to $50,000,000. Additionally, $5,000,000 is allocated annually for the Inspector General of the Department of Housing and Urban Development to combat violent crime in public housing. The Low-Income Housing Preservation and Resident Homeownership Act is amended to extend deadlines to 1995 for acquisition grants and technical assistance. Section 236 Rental Assistance Fund deadlines are also extended to September 30, 1995. Additionally, amendments are made to provide emergency homeownership counseling. Amendments are made to various housing acts, extending deadlines to 1995 for acquisition grants and technical assistance. Emergency homeownership counseling is also provided. Amendments to housing acts extend deadlines for acquisition grants and technical assistance to 1995. Emergency homeownership counseling is also included. Conversion of the Tamaqua Highrise project in Pennsylvania to tenant-based assistance under section 8 of the United States Housing Act of 1937 is authorized. Rehabilitation activities by E.T.C. Enterprises are required to comply with the rehabilitation requirement. Rehabilitation activities by E.T.C. Enterprises and Pennrose Properties for low-income families and senior citizens in New Jersey are deemed to have been conducted with approval from the Secretary of Housing and Urban Development under the United States Housing Act of 1937. The Independent Agencies Appropriations Act, 1988 is amended to authorize the conversion of Pine Tower Apartments in Bay City, Michigan from a leased housing contract to a project-based rental assistance contract under section 8 of the United States Housing Act of 1937. Repayment required for amounts received under the comprehensive improvement assistance program for the Pine Tower Apartment project and formula in section 14(k) of the United States Housing Act of 1937. SEC. 3. RURAL HOUSING. The text chunk discusses amendments to the Housing Act of 1949 related to underserved areas and rural multifamily rental housing. Amendments include changes to loan periods and payment schedules. Amendments to the Housing Act of 1949 include a schedule for loan amortization over 50 years, payment deadlines, rural rental housing funds, loan guarantees for multifamily housing, and eligibility for rural homeownership loans in specific areas like Pine View West Subdivision. Amendments to the Housing Act of 1949 include defining rural areas for properties in Pine View West Subdivision, Gibsonville, North Carolina, and cities of South Tucson, Arizona. SEC. 4. Amendments to multifamily housing finance and assessment collection dates for the Office of Federal Housing Enterprise Oversight. SEC. 5. Community development initiatives. Amendments are made to certain CDBG assistance and CDBG public services limitations, extending the applicability beyond fiscal year 1995. Cities in California are allowed to use a limited percentage of assistance for specific purposes in fiscal year 1995. Cities in Pennsylvania, specifically Pittsburgh and Wilkes-Barre, are granted the ability to retain and use urban development action grant funds for specific projects within a certain timeframe. The Northeastern Pennsylvania Economic Development project must begin within 6 months of the Act's enactment. The Secretary of Housing and Urban Development will cancel the indebtedness of Richmond, Virginia, and Lockport Township, Illinois, related to specific urban renewal programs and public facilities loans. Lockport Township, Illinois, is relieved of liability for a loan balance, interest, and fees. Budget compliance is subject to appropriation Acts. The Secretary may use insurance authority for loans under the New Towns Demonstration Program. The National Housing Act allows commitments to insure loans and mortgages in fiscal year 1995. Second mortgage assistance and community development assistance are also authorized for appropriations in the same year. Authorization of appropriations for fiscal year 1995 for economic development grants under the Housing and Community Development Act of 1974. Specifically, a grant of $3,650,000 is allocated to the Earth Conservancy in Luzerne County, Pennsylvania for innovative environmental technologies to reclaim land damaged by anthracite coal mining activities. SEC. 6. MISCELLANEOUS PROVISIONS. (a) State Agencies as Sureties.--Section 9304 of title 31, United States Code, is amended to allow State agencies to be treated as surety corporations for certain purposes. User fees collected by the Financial Management Services can be retained by the agency without fiscal year limitation. (b) Clarification of Effective Date for Amendment Relating to Commercial Mortgage Related Securities.--Section 347(d) of the Riegle Community Development and Regulatory Improvement Act of 1994 is amended regarding commercial mortgage-related securities. The Housing Programs Extension Act of 1994 is amended to specify the effective date of the amendment, with exceptions for national and insured state banks. The Housing Programs Extension Act of 1994 was passed by the House of Representatives on October 7, 1994.
